courses.subject: LSED
courses.title: Pedagogical Content Knowledge in Science, Technology and the Environment
courses.description:
This course aims at helping students to acquire pedagogical content knowledge in the Area of “Science, Technology and the Environment”. It enables students to acquire a deeper understanding of subject knowledge in this specific Area of Study, think about subject knowledge from the students’ perspectives, apply subject knowledge from the perspective of multidisciplinary teaching, and organize instructional strategies of issue-based teaching in relevant conceptual and contextual considerations.
The focus will be placed on understanding the scientific and technological principles and social implications of “Public Health and Technology” and “Energy and the Environment”. Students will be guided to apply relevant subject knowledge and skills in these areas to discuss and enquire into various related issues in order to reach evidence-based judgment and decisions. The implications of the processes and the results from these enquiries on the learning and teaching of Liberal Studies will be fully discussed.

- Liberal studies –What are its values as a compulsory subject in senior secondary? What are the problems, difficulties and issues around teaching LS?

- Assessment issues in LS - questions analysis of DSE paper

- What constitutes the pedagogical content knowledge (PCK) for liberal studies?

- Curriculum planning - unit plan, module plan and year plan

- Curriculum framework of modules 5 and 6

- What is public health?

- A history of understandings of disease and health

- Reasoning about causation in health issues

- A critical appraisal of health claims

- Environmental problems and Environmental philosophy

- Climate changes and related political issues

- A framework of issue analysis

- Issue analysis of public health and environmental issues

- Teaching by issue enquiry approach I

- Group presentation of analysis on environmental issues and public health issues

- Teaching by issue enquiry approach II

- Microteaching

courses.title: Pedagogical Content Knowledge in Society and Culture
courses.description:
This course aims at helping students to acquire pedagogical content knowledge in the Area of “Society and Culture”. It enables students to acquire a deeper understanding of subject knowledge in this specific Area of Study, think about subject knowledge from the students’ perspectives, apply subject knowledge from the perspective of multidisciplinary teaching, and organize instructional strategies of issue-based teaching in relevant conceptual and contextual considerations.
The Area of Study includes the following modules: Hong Kong Today, Modern China and Globalization. The focus of this course will be placed on enabling students to analyze the human conditions in certain social development and cultural contexts, with reference to their related subject knowledge and concepts from multi-disciplinary perspectives. In addition, issues-based teaching will be adopted to facilitate the students to reflect on the contradictions and values which have been embedded in various phenomena.

courses.subject: LSED
courses.title: Foundations of Disciplinary Knowledge and General Education
courses.description:
This course aims to introduce the theoretical and pedagogical nature of Liberal Studies (LS) and its foundational knowledge to students. In the first part of the course, students will be provided an overview on the theoretical and pedagogical underpinnings of the subject, including the curriculum classification “integrated curriculum”; the guiding philosophical principles “constructivist and student-centered approaches”; and pedagogic practice “issue-enquiry approach.”.
In the second part of the course, the liberal studies approach to knowledge and education will be applied to inquire into three areas of studies in the context of the twenty-first century. The areas are (1) self and personal development, (2) society and culture, and (3) science, technology and the environment. These three areas are basically in correspondence with the three areas of study stipulated in syllabus of the Liberal Studies in the Hong Kong senior-secondary curriculum. In each area, concepts and theories related to the areas of inquiry are introduced. It attempts to lay the pedagogical foundation for the teaching and learning of liberal studies in secondary schools in Hong Kong Special Administrative Region.

courses.description: This course aims to help students understand the nature of Liberal Studies and its theoretical and pedagogical foundations. Various perspectives on Liberal Studies and different interpretations of its genesis and its significance will be explored. Issue-based inquiry and its variations will be introduced and examined. The conceptual and pedagogical features of various methods of inquiry, including conceptual, factual, valuative and critical, will be explicated using issues related to Liberal Studies curriculum in Hong Kong secondary schools.

courses.title: Pedagogical Content Knowledge in Self and Personal Development
courses.description:
This course aims to facilitate students’ acquisition of the pedagogical content knowledge in the area of "Self and Personal Development". It enables students to develop a more comprehensive understanding of the subject knowledge in this specific area of study, think about subject knowledge from the learners' perspectives, apply subject knowledge from the perspective of multi-disciplinary teaching, and organize instructional strategies of issue-based teaching.
The focus will be placed on understanding personal development and interpersonal relationships in the context of family, peers, and society. Pedagogical strategies like group discussion, debate, role-play, news analysis and independent-enquiry studies, etc. will be introduced to illustrate how the various issues in the module can be addressed.

courses.subject: LSED
courses.title: Independent Enquiry Studies (I): Research Methods
courses.description:
This course aims to help students understand research process and common research methodology relevant to Independent Enquiry Studies (IES). It introduces student skills including: (a) develop research questions, (b) design a research plan to collect quantitative and/or qualitative data, (c) conduct basic statistical and qualitative data analyses and (d) interpret and discuss results. Students will carry out a group research project to consolidate these skills. These skills prepare students to conduct research projects independently.

Assessment Criteria:
Participation in Class Discussion & In-class Exercises (10%)
Attendance & active participations are expected.

Group project presentation (45%)
Each group would conduct a 20-mins presentation and lead the following 10-mins Q&A section. 35% of the course assessment would be allocated to the group presentation, 5% would be marked on the basis of your constructive feedbacks or critical comments on others’ presentations during the Q&A sections, and another 5% would be given by your groupmates as peer-evaluation.

Literature Review Assignment (45%)
Each student is required to select a research paper from the group project reading and provide a critique with the following sections:
• A brief and precise summary of the research background, objectives and the research design. [10%]
• Critical comment on its strength and weakness. [12%]
• What methodological and/or ethical issues would you like to raise for further discussion? [8%]
• How does this research contribute to your group research project? [5%]
• What further studies would you suggest? Please briefly describe and explain. [5%]
• Format & Writing quality. [3% + 2%]
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students should be able to:

1. understand the nature of Independent Enquiry Studies

2. review literature systematically and formulate a research hypothesis

3. execute various common research methods in data collection including questionnaire survey, observation, and interview

4. understand issues on ethical consideration and sampling in research

5. apply basic statistical concepts to analyze data

6. summarize key research findings and discuss them cohesively
courses.course_syllabus:
How to develop research questions

Metaphor of Research: The Null Hypothesis

Experimental Study Design & Longitudinal Study Design

- Concept of p-value

- Chi Square Test

- Questionnaire & Inventories

- Consent & Debriefing Forms

- Design & Reliability of Questionnaire

- Coding & Data Sheet

- Sampling

- Research Ethics

Correlational Analysis

Narrative Inquiry & Textual analysis

Issues in Data Collection and Data Analysis

Issues in Presenting Results, Discussion & Limitations

Researcher Reflections: Inquiry-based Learning
